So I looked into the "references" for this video and I must say I am kind of disappointed in Asapscience for this video. There are a number of problems with the sources, so I will lay them out in the order that they appear in the description (they are not in the order that they appear in the video, nor are there time stamps for correct sitation). Heads up, this is a novel of a comment, but you should give it a read through if you are curious about the sources for this video.

1-A) This is a secondary source. This is an improper sourcing technique and is thus void. This links to a magazine article talking about a study and not the study itself, and as such, is not a proper source for the claims made in the video (in reference to neuro-reactions in participants in response to images of mutilation).

2-B): This study did not actually conclude that there are any differences in cognitive styles but instead proposed the possibility of such. The brain scans did show differences that were relayed in this video (except it was the right amygdala, not the entire amygdala complex), and they made no conclusion on the effects of such differences. The scale for political belief was also conducted in a very poor manner of 1–5, with 1 being "very liberal" and 5 being "very conservative" without any definitions of terminology. Due to poor data methodology, this source should not be used as concrete evidence of anything, and doing the contrary is poor scientific form.

3-D): This source is a paid-only resource, meaning that it should not be used as a primary source unless you can accurately abstract the research in an easily accessable manner. Due to the manner of this research, it would also likely involve self-identification, which can cause inaccurate data collection, but this is mostly speculation as I have no access to this source at this time.

4—D) Repeat of point 3. It is a poor sourcing technique to link to a pay wall unless it is absolutely necessary.

5-A) This link was an interesting read with some great insight into the historical weaponization of psychology for political reasons as done by the Nazis after their defeat in WW2. It is also a rather long article that would have benefited from a proper sourcing technique on behalf of asapscience to reference a particular section of this article or to directly link to a primary source used by this article instead of leaving this to anyone attempting to fact check their research for this video.

6.-D) Repeat of point 3. It is a poor sourcing technique to link to a pay wall unless it is absolutely necessary.

7-C): This source is using the EI (emotional intelligence) model, which has been called into question as an effective measure of emotional response in the past. Discarding that concern, this research measured the ability of a person to gauge the emotional reaction depicted in an image and choose to "approach" or "avoid". This research would not be conclusive of emotional intelligence but would rather show a difference in threat management, which would be dependent on too many factors to be conclusive with such a small sample size (63) which were all recruited locally through word of mouth. This means that it cannot be used to extrapolate data from it or even conclude meaningful evidence without the disclaimer of possible localization of specific responses due to social factors. For an example of a social factor difference, it may be commonly accepted that people should avoid angry individuals in one area, but in a smaller community it may be accepted that you should attempt to diffuse the situation. Both responses would skew the data.

At this point, I have grown bored of disputing the sources on a point-for-point level as each source I have covered so far has all been very weak or has been taken out of their original context. Sources 8–12 may be great, but the sources above have either been:

A) Incorrectly sourced, either through the use of a secondary source or by failing to accurately source a specific section discussing the topic at hand.
B) Removed from context, as in source 2.
C) The studies used questionable methodologies that could skew the results and, as a result, should not be cited if you want to be accurate.
D) are placed behind a pay-wall, with only the abstract available to the public. An abstract of the research can be helpful but should not be the only available section of a source.


In conclusion, this video is highly questionable and uses very suspect sources (at points, inaccurately relaying information from linked sources). The idea of there being neurological differences between political camps is an interesting proposal, but I must urge people that watch this to take all the information contained within it with a hefty pinch of salt. This research (even if it were all accurate) would also only be the result of averages within small sample sizes, which couldn't be accurately extrapolated due to the number of potential factors that would be at play (social factors, individual identification of terms, potential regional biases, etc.) and the sample size used.

That was an interesting video, but it misses one crucial point. In the scope of political opinions it's exceptionally important to recognize how the information we get shapes our worldview. It's hard to overestimate how different the pictures of the world based on different fact samples are. People with the same way of thinking and brains functioning virtually in the same manner can come to vastly different conclusions if they exist in different conditions and in different informational environment. The questions of politics ARE the questions of truth, so it's not just about „neither good nor bad“ differences. It's also about one people being closer to truth than others. And even though it also depends on the way of thinking, it's obvious that it relies on the information fed to the person, including propaganda, more heavily.

And also... Why calling the right wing and the left wing conservatives and liberals? There aren't only conservatives on the right: you can also find alt-right and fascists there. And on the left you can also see social democrats, socialists, including democratic socialists, and communists. Personally, being a socialist I'm not content with not being properly represented here, that is, being insinuatively added to liberals, who I don't belong to. Deeper look into human beings with radical political views would give a broader picture of the differences in the way of thinking, since that doesn't boil down to just preferences; these differences are crucial and serious, so the bigger differences in the way of thought are to be expected. Such a shame no one checked this thing out, or in any case didn't mention checking it in this video.

The rights of states  pitted against the rights of the people  The enumerated powers that are listed in the Constitution include exclusive federal powers, as well as concurrent powers that are shared with the states, and all of those powers are contrasted with the reserved powers—also called states' rights—that only the states possess.  In American political discourse, states' rights are political powers held for the state governments rather than the federal government according to the United States Constitutionand and the 1969 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The very definition of sovereignty entitles states to non-intervention in their domestic affairs. The idea of Universal Human Rights and the protection of an individual within a state would appear to come into direct conflict with this very definition. As such, International Human Rights obligations are regularly seen as “eroding state sovereignty” (Ayoob, 2001:93).  The coexistence of the two has not been easy; more often than not the two principles have confronted rather than partnered. By definition, Human Rights give the basic liberties and freedoms entitled to all simply because of being human. The institutionalisation of Human Rights in the international system is a relatively new concept. It wasn’t until after the Second World War that the challenge of Human Rights upon state sovereignty emerged.. The rapid growth in the protection of Human Rights is less a challenge on the very concept of sovereignty, rather a re-definition.It is important to note that theoretically, any such promotion of universal Human Rights by the international community.  is a restraint on a states’ sovereignty

But for the heck of it here is a study that sought to answer which is more intelligent . Carl (2014) analysed data from the U.S. General Social Survey (GSS), and found that individuals who identify as Republican have slightly higher verbal intelligence than those who identify as Democrat. An important qualification was that the measure of verbal intelligence used was relatively crude, namely a 10-word vocabulary test. This study examines three other measures of cognitive ability from the GSS: a test of probability knowledge, a test of verbal reasoning, and an assessment by the interviewer of how well the respondent understood the survey questions. In all three cases, individuals who identify as Republican score slightly higher than those who identify as Democrat; the unadjusted differences are 1–3 IQ points, 2–4 IQ points and 2–3 IQ points, respectively. Path analyses indicate that the associations between cognitive ability and party identity are largely but not totally accounted for by socio-economic position: individuals with higher cognitive ability tend to have better socio-economic positions, and individuals with better socio-economic positions are more likely to identify as Republican. These results are consistent with Carl's (2014) hypothesis that higher intelligence among classically liberal Republicans compensates for lower intelligence among socially conservative Republicans.

I call myself a conservative republican, but I guess with some of my views some might be seen as more independent. First off, I love my country. I favor capitalism , support the 2nd amendment, believe in hard work and personal responsibility, tend to be "old fashioned" in some ways, support the military and police, and want lower taxes for the average citizen. I'm also Catholic and middle class from a (very moderate) democrat household....BUT

Yes, the US is not perfect, and has done and continues to do shitty things. But that doesn't change all the amazing and innovative things we've done and still do as well. I will agree capitalism is a far from perfect system, Imho it is the best one we have. I still believe in background checks, and believe any citizen (who is responsible, ethical, and mentally healthy) should be able to own a gun. I abhor gun violence, and dangerous individuals should be kept away from them. I 100% support the legalization and decriminalization of marijuana, and possibly other drugs like shrooms. I have no problem with LGBT rights and marriage, as long as they treat me and everyone else with respect and do not "force" anything on anyone. I think budgets towards military and police could be cut (not exponentially but slowly over time) to go towards things like health and education to prevent poverty and police issues. I support free speech to death and don't believe in censorship unless it is violent, dangerous, or blatant propaganda/fake news. I am not a socialist but I agree that the rich should pay higher taxes, I could flirt with the idea of free healthcare (or at the very least more affordable) and definitely think college should be cheaper ( but not free.). I enjoy edgy jokes and movies but actual racism and bigotry piss me off. I hate extremists on both sides, communism and fascism are both awful ideologies.

At times, especially when online talking about politics, I can come off as a pissed off conservative with a "boomer" mindset or maybe even mistaken for far right. Rest assured everything I said is as truthful as I can be about my stances on pretty much everything I can think of. I will admit to having a bias towards republicans/patriotism, and over the last few months with everything going on, have made a goal to be more open minded and reasonable, and strive more towards facts and goodwill, rather than talking points and blindly siding with others who agree with me on some things but not others.

Anyway, there's my novel of a comment. Would love to hear about others views and discuss in a mature and rational manner :)

I think that conservatives and liberals are divided by one thing, and that is which aspects they look at things.

Conservatives usually look at things from more organized, statistical, and definite, aspects - such as economic, physical, and mental. This helps them in things such as politics and problem solving, but not in empathizing and communicating; which is the reason why they're a lot more quiet, stoick, and possibly boring than their counterpart.

Liberals are the exact opposite. They like to percieve things from more social, artistic, and emotional aspects. No offense, but this can possibly cause them to make more inaccurate political or economic choices and may cause them to be impulsive or abnoxious; but on a better note they are very social, empathetic, kind, and entertaining - this is why liberals have a much greater influence on media and society. They would love for everyone to be happy and friendly and always appreciate new and unique things, even if those things aren't that great.

Now, there are points at which one can be too liberal or too conservative, which surprisingly leads to the same flaws: stubbornness and pride. This causes liberals too sadly lose a lot empathy and forgivingness, and it causes conservatives to hate with no sympathy or open-mindedness at all to those against them. This is what I consider to be the extreme of either side.

I, however, constantly switch between the two. When it comes to subjects such politics, science, morality, and mathematics tend to look at it in a conservative way. But whenever I am drawing, designing, writing, producing music, or socializing I think similarly to how liberals think.

I believe we need either side. Through the constant contending and debating between both liberals and conservatives our society gets increasingly refined to a perfect balance between practicality and abstractness.

This should not be understood as a difference in cognitive or intellectual capacity. The primary differences (I see) between liberals and conservatives are their perspectives and worldview, not their objectives nor intelligence. The producers mentioned reactions to severe injuries. It’s much like Western medicine versus eastern medicine. Relief is both their objectives, but they differ with risks and robustness. Western medicine (let’s say liberal) tends to treat the symptom for timely relief but discount side effects, while eastern medicine (let’s say conservative) seeks the root cause/weakness even if not so comfortable or timely. Think of it as adding shingles over the leaks in a roof (even if it eventually collapses), versus removing and replacing the entire roof (even if it’s cold winter). In the end the question is “What price are they willing to pay to reach their objective?” Quick relief with often harsh side effects and no cure, or difficult treatment with longer lasting results or even a cure? There is one mistake with this type of study in my opinion. Not saying any one side is better than another. But if fear is justified, then it makes sense to deal with it. Fear is so often seen as a weakness or negative emotion. But let's put it this way, to a conservative, it is like when you have not maintained your house and you have a lot of problems develop. You say, well, i am afraid if i don't fix it now, it will just get worse. So, let's get our house in order, fix the roof, fix the foundation, redo the plumbing etc. In that case, it would be a mistake to just keep doing what you have been doing and let your house deteriorate.

So, more accurately, liberals like change and new things and creativity, conservatives like order, managing risks and threats, and keeping things the way they are . A country or society needs both in balance in my opinion.

Look into the Big 5 Behavioral Traits. It's a robust statistics-based construct that rates personality based on 5 scales/traits. You can rank either low or high in each trait, and combinations rather accurately predict a liberal or conservative personality. And then there is strong correlation between personality and how a person tends to vote over time.
Openness -- the creative dimension. Openness to new ideas, lateral thinking, thinking outside the box.
Conscientiousness -- the dimension of orderliness and duty, and of continuing to do things that work
Extroversion -- the sociability, talkativeness, assertiveness, and excitability dimension
Agreeablness -- the kind, supportive, cooperative, don't upset the boat, go with the flow dimension
Neurosity -- sensitivity to negative emotions.  


A combination of high Openness Extroversion and Agreeableness and low Conscientiousness tends to make one's personality more Liberal
Whereas high Conscientiousness and low Openness tends to predict Conservative personality -- with low Neurosity factoring in. 


And consider that high Agreeableness crossed with high Neurosity together form what we call "the maternal instincts" -- and low Agreeableness is what causes men as a group to be more assertive, competative, and accounts for the male incarceration rate.  
Neurosity sounds like a negative, but it is what allows moms to be extraordinarily sensitive to the emotional needs of their child and creates the bubble of security around them when they are at their most vulnerable (arguably up to about age 4, where they need to start taking risks and celebrate their anti-fragile nature or risk crippling infantilization that will forever put them at an increasing disadvantage against their peers).
But high Trait-Neurosity in women as a group also accounts for the higher rate of mental illness, usually in the genre of anxiety disorders.

The modern right wing is moving away from status Quo conservatism- free trade, low taxes and judicial Precedence in court rulings  and moving towards traditional conservatism which is a philosophy emphasizing the need for the principles of a transcendent moral order, which empathizes bonds of social order and the defense of ancestral institutions over hyper-individualism. The main differences I see is conservatives believe that any social unrest will lead to anarchy and thus why they support strong law enforcement to uphold social order while left leading people believe in changing the status quo by protest, boycott and even violence(Antifa)  and overall  belief in breaking the system to re-build a better system, sorta resembles the French Revolution style social change. Democrat vs Liberal =/= Liberal vs Conservative


Nor is this left vs right.
Conservatism is the political philosophy of preservation of traditional cultural norms. In other words, protection of national culture and structure.
Liberalism is the political philosophy of the protection and enhancement of individual liberty as the core tenet and starting point of all policy, with a strong emphasis on equal opportunity.


One can in fact be both, as I am. The US political parties are also both significantly right of centre to most countries. In modern usage, terms have been thrown around with completely false meanings. Liberal has become synonymous with social progressivism and social justice. (Progressivism is also not a notion of the left alone. Canada's Progressive Conservative party is an example of the combination of both elements into one central party that falls right of centre in Canadian politics). Conservatism has become synonymous with free market and preservation of liberty in constitutional rights....ironically, the very core tenets of classical Liberalism.


The difference here is between thinking in terms of progressivism and conservatism, more than Liberal and conservative. And the differences are very well described by social psychologist Jonathan Haidt here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8SOQduoLgRw&index=2&list=PL_ENk0_8p9RuOMLI-E8QVwqh2sqn2LTio&t=484s

In a new study of people in 16 different countries, researchers from the University of Southern California and the University of Utah found that conservatives reported feeling there was more meaning and purpose in life than liberals did.




The authors performed a series of five studies, all of which replicated each others’ findings. Conservatives found life more meaningful in data sets from several countries in the early 1980s, in a nationally representative data set of Americans in 2007, and in data collected between 2010 and 2017. In other data sets, conservatives found greater meaning in life when the measures were taken at the end of every day for two weeks. They were also more likely to feel that their lives had “a clear sense of purpose” at any given moment.

False dichotomies prompted by rigid group identity. Since the US has a strong two-party system heavily reinforced by the two in charge, many humans (as humans are social animals) tend to form strong bonds with one of those two parties, becoming emotional and irrational when the beliefs that helped to form those bonds get challenged.

However, not everyone can easily fit into one of those two groups, so both groups tend to treat those outside the group as traitors, or as part of “the enemy”... until they need those outsiders for something, like swaying an election in favor of their group.

One thing that could help, albeit a little bit, would be to recognize that there are other groups beyond the major two, with thoughts and goals of their own, instead of treating everything like it’s “us vs. them.”

The evidence actually indicates that conservatives understand liberals quite well, but the converse is not true. Moral psychologist Jonathan Haidt administered a 100-question survey to 1000 liberals and 1000 conservatives, and then also had them fill it out while pretending to answer as the "other side" would. What he found was that the conservatives pretending to be liberal were much closer to the actual liberal responses than the liberals pretending to be conservative were to the actual conservative responses. He used this to argue for his moral foundations theory, detailed in his book The Righteous Mind, which I highly recommend.

I really don’t like when neurobiology research is used to try and make conclusions about complex cognitive processes. The field isn’t understood enough to make those kind of conclusions from 1 study. The reason is that, if you have studied pain, you would know that we have very little information on how pain is actually encoded once it enters cortex. Saying that more S2 activation encodes for “more pain” is really going for a reach. Sure, that’s the answer they want to see, especially if their study centers around something like politics, but often times our biases can lead us to see results that aren’t actually there. S2 doesn’t only process pain information, and pain information is sent to a multitude of locations, not just S2. It is interesting that the two groups are different in some way, but we can’t say for sure that one group is in more “pain” than the other, because we don’t fully understand how that pain is represented in cortex. I don’t know if the researchers came to that conclusion or if the content creators paraphrased, I would have to read the paper myself to find out more.

Also, that genetic study is most likely more of an environmental factor, seeing how we learn our morals and ideologies mainly from our parents for the early years of our lives. That first study he points out kinda implies that there’s some set of “liberal” or “conservative” genes, when that would be a ridiculous conclusion to jump to from a molecular study.

Philosophically speaking, which views are morally correct and which are errant? Which views are rational and which irrational? These psychologizing arguments always end up seeming pseudo scientific to me. In this case someone is attributing political differences - i.e variance in the social sphere - by differences in the brain. The implication is that politics are explainable not in terms of concrete, social conflict between interest groups but by predetermined differences in their brains. This is, imo, mistaking an effect for a cause.

I would say that our social conflicts shape our brain chemistry not vice versa. What we're seeing here is the product of a specific type of society (namely American society) and the effects on the brain are predetermined by the ideological landscape which the studies participants orient themselves in (I.e american liberals being brought up on cultural relativism, individualist humanism etc while republicans are likely to be focused on values of individual discipline, puritan ethics and a view of succes as hinged upon the individual not society in general).

For some reason this kind of research scares me. I think we’re all human beings and are much more similar than we are different. If we start measuring and quantifying these differences, it’s likely that we would understand each other less and some could possibly assert superiority over the other brain type. For example some one could claim the “liberal” or “conservative” brain is superior and entitle that group to certain privileges while oppressing the opposite group. This is clearly a very pessimistic view, but from the perspective of world history, humans have often mistreated those of different characteristics. For example: Racism, sexism, religious persecution, and many other forms of bigotry. The last thing I want is Brain-ism. I’d hope we would be able to embrace these differences and come together, but I fear these differences will drive us further apart if we validate them with research.

It’s as if the comment section is acting as our collective mind, and the deeper we go, the more we realize how uneducated we truly are. Comments slowly start leaking minor errors. One letter is missed, and then two. Suddenly, my mouse takes control, acting on its own volition. My scroll wheel breaks the sound barrier! Firefox can barely handle the speed at which it has to load comments. 3K, 4K, 5K comments rush past my face in a barrage of black and white sludge. My mind is flooded with “XD” and “NPC” followed by the occasional mention of Ben Shapiro. My life flashes before my eyes as liberals provide me with quotes from CNN and MSNBC anchors, and conservatives provide me with FOX News talking points and Trump chants. I peer out of the windowsill directly to my left, I see Vladimir hundreds of miles away standing on the Russian coast. (the view from Alaska is unbeatable!) And almost as if it was fate, a large animal that I could only describe as a mix between a donkey and an elephant knocks me unconscious. Hours, days, months pass. What I've learned from people far smarter than me, is that conservatives keep things running smoothly, maintain organization, and ensure the necessary work gets done. While liberals are the ones who come up with new and innovative ideas and blaze new trails and explore more efficient new methods of getting things done.

Or essentially, its sort of like liberals are the entrepreneurs who come up with the vision/ideas for a company while conservatives are like the business men who ensure the company runs smoothly on those new ideas.

Without liberals, the company breaks down because they never grow or change with the times and can't always respond to new competition and obstacles in a successful way. And they're more likely to rigidly follow fixed rules/routines which don't allow for much creativity or expansion, which would result in the company's eventual decay and demise.

But without conservatives, those new innovations and ideas crash and burn without the proper structure and discipline needed to get those ideas off the ground and to implement them effectively. And if those new methods/ideas happen to not be feasible, conservatives arent there to vet those liberal ideas to be sure they're actually possible or practical with the resources/time/manpower/etc available, thus resulting in a failed company yet again.

So, in other words, we need each other. And it's highly beneficial for everyone if we would work together and try to communicate rather than be so divided and hateful towards each other.

Maybe this view of liberals/conservatives is inaccurate, but it's consistent with my experience with such people in my life. And regardless, I do think more unity and understanding between the parties is obviously better than treating all who disagree with you as morally inferior simpletons.
